Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Postdischarge Video-Based Virtual Visits vs. In-Person Follow-Up

Participants.evidence: patients from a small community hospital and a large tertiary care hospital. Participants included those undergoing minimally invasive appendectomy or cholecystectomy.

Intervention.evidence: randomisation was performed in a 2:1 ratio to either video-based virtual visits or in-person visits

Objective.evidence: This study aims to assess the noninferiority of virtual visits compared to in-person follow-up in terms of 30-day hospital encounter rates.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the percentage of patients experiencing a 30-day hospital encounter

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: using a computer-generated sequence with concealed allocation

Number_Randomised.evidence: 432 were randomised, with 289 assigned to the virtual group and 143 to the in-person group

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis followed an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The hospital encounter rate was noninferior for virtual visits (12.8% vs. 13.3% for in-person, Δ 0.5% with 1-sided 95% CI, −∞ to 5.2%).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
